newsitem.title: USA: Ag trade opportunity in East, Central Europe-USDA.
newsitem.headline: Ag trade opportunity in East, Central Europe-USDA.

text.p: Central and Eastern Europe offer a trade opportunity for U.S. poultry meat, oilseeds and processed foods, an Agricutlure Department official said Tuesday.
Deputy Agriculture Undersecretary James Schroeder said there also were opportunities for food processing equipment and joint ventures in food marketing and processing.

At a USDA-sponsored conference, Schroeder and a World Bank analyst said the region, through its desire to join the European Union, would put pressure on Europe to reform its farm support program. Otherwise, farm costs could soar.
Schroeder and World Bank analyst Michel Debatisse said Central and Eastern Europe already was a sizable agricultural force and output could expand with access to EU markets.
Four of the region's nations -- Romania, Hungary, Poland and Czech Republic -- produce one-third as much grain as the 15 members of the EU, Debatisse said.
In general, the region provides far less government support to farmers than the EU, so an influx of new EU members could quickly drive up farm subsidy costs without reform.
The EU has begun initial steps toward a new round of ag reform since the new world trade agreement took effect.
Schroeder said the United States wanted to see the EU move toward freer agricultural trade. He declined to be more specific.
At present, the EU holds the lion's share of ag trade with Central and Eastern Europe. The U.S. share is 5-10 percent.
Prospects for sales of U.S. bulk goods, he said, were affected by weather, ag reforms and preferences given to EU.
Ten of the region's nations have requested membership in EU. No timetable has been set. Some hope to join by 2005.
